RT @ed_hawkins: Storm Ulysses - February 26-27 1903 - would have more severe consequences if it occurred now compared to 120 years ago: more rainfall (+10%/K) & stronger winds. 

Paper on storm: https://nhess.copernicus.org/articles/23/1465/2023/nhess-23-1465-2023.html

Preprint in discussion on consequences: https://egusphere.copernicus.org/preprints/2023/egusphere-2023-665/

RT @ed_hawkins: Storm Ulysses - February 26-27 1903 - would have more severe consequences if it occurred now compared to 120 years ago: more rainfall (+10%/K) & stronger winds. 

Paper on storm: https://nhess.copernicus.org/articles/23/1465/2023/nhess-23-1465-2023.html

Preprint in discussion on consequences: https://egusphere.copernicus.org/preprints/2023/egusphere-2023-665/

text:

text:
If you are interested in soil physics and hydrology, come after the #EGU23 coffee break (16:15-18h) to hall A (floor 2, red zone), to see Filip Kialka's poster A.196.

He will explain you our work modelling the effect of (de)compaction on soil hydraulic properties.

text: Turns out last year‚Äôs seismic swarm on the Northern MAR was even more interesting than it first seemed‚Ä¶ so we made an #EGU23 poster about it! Come check it out today at 2 pm, board X2.128! https://meetingorganizer.copernicus.org/EGU23/EGU23-7479.html ¬´ jaodynamics: The Mid-Atlantic Ridge is lighting up! Seismicity started on Monday near the Charlie-Gibbs transform, with an M5.8 normal faulting event. Has been migrating south at ~1 km/hr since then. A once-in-50-yr dike intrusion event? (EQs relocation courtesy of G. Ekstrom @LamontEarth) üåã https://twitter.com/jaodynamics/status/1575521929125105664/video/1 ‚Äî https://twitter.com/jaodynamics/status/1575521929125105664 ¬ª
user_description: Geodynamicist @Geosciences_ENS / @CNRS. I stretch, squeeze and break *theoretical* tectonic plates for a living.
